list-item.p: I am not sure if this is pertinent, as I am paid a salary through Children's Hospital Los Angeles. Nevertheless, In the past two years, some of my salary support has come from industry studies examining medications for intractable epilepsy. GW Pharmaceuticals is the company and they are based in the United Kingdom. I do not receive any direct payments from them or any bonuses, etc. and I am not the PI on these studies. I complete suicide assessments and neuropsychological evaluations, when applicable, on these studies.

This may not be relevant, as I do not receive any payments directly, nor am I the PI on the study, but I do participate on an NIH grant examining oxygen manipulations in patients with sickle cell disease, and this covers a small portion of my salary at Children's Hospital Los Angeles. My role is to gather neuropsychological data and collaborate on imaging studies and several manuscripts.

fn.p: These authors contributed equally to this work.
Coinvestigators of the NF Clinical Trials Consortium are listed at Neurology.org.
Go to Neurology.org for full disclosures. Funding information and disclosures deemed relevant by the authors, if any, are provided at the end of the article.

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To assess the efficacy of lovastatin on visuospatial learning and attention for treating cognitive and behavioral deficits in children with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: A multicenter, international, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial was conducted between July 2009 and May 2014 as part of the NF Clinical Trials Consortium. Children with NF1 aged 815 years were screened for visuospatial learning or attention deficits (n = 272); 146 children demonstrated deficits at baseline and were randomly assigned to lovastatin (n = 74; 40 mg/d) or placebo (n = 70). Treatment was administered once daily for 16 weeks. Primary outcomes were total errors on the Cambridge Neuropsychological Test Automated Battery Paired Associate Learning task (visuospatial learning) and the Score subtest from the Test of Everyday Attention for Children (sustained attention). Secondary outcomes measured executive function, attention, visuospatial skills, behavior, and quality of life. Primary analyses were performed on the intention-to-treat population.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Lovastatin had no significant effect on primary outcomes after 16 weeks of treatment: visuospatial learning (Cohen d = 0.15, 95% confidence interval 0.47 to 0.18) or sustained attention (Cohen d = 0.19, 95% confidence interval 0.14 to 0.53). Lovastatin was well tolerated, with no increase in reported adverse events compared to placebo.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Lovastatin administered once daily for 16 weeks did not improve visuospatial learning or attention in children with NF1 and is not recommended for amelioration of cognitive deficits in this population.

sec.title: ClinicalTrials.gov identifier:
sec.p: This study was registered at ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT00853580) and Australian New Zealand Clinical Trials Registry (ACTRN12607000560493).

sec.title: Classification of evidence:
sec.p: This study provides Class I evidence that for children with NF1, lovastatin does not improve visuospatial learning or attention deficits.
